channel.title: MoparClassic High Scores
channel.description:
How hard would it be to implement a high score viewing interface within the game client? It just struck me as a reasonable approach that wouldn't necessitate poor man's log shipping (as discussed in the stickied topic).
The way I see it, the only things a website are typically used for are:
[ol][li]Account creation (which is going to be handled through the client now).[/li] [li]Marketplace[/li] [li]High score viewing.[/li][/ol]
If we used reddit for the marketplace, and added a high score facility within the client, then there would be no more need for a website in my opinion.
Discuss.

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @cleako cleako
item.description:
@cleako wrote:

Is using a larger client window size out of the question? RS2 and RS3 went much larger. I find zooming in a bit closer with a larger client viewing area makes a comfortable playing mode for me.

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Yeah, you’re probably right. With javascript pagination I suppose it’s simpler to just distribute a html file with some inline javascript and then a second javascript file with the json.

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:6, topic:528260”]I wasn’t talking about loading a site within the client so much as introducing some new packets that would allow for pagination and searching my username.

So you’d basically have these client to server packets:

  1. Search by player name.
  2. Search by skill, page number. (Opcode, skill id, page number).
  3. Search by rank (Opcode, skill id, rank).

The search by player name would simply return the stats for that player, or a ‘not found’ code.
The search by skill would involve sending a valid skill id to order by that skill, or a negative skill id to indicate ordering by overall level. It would also send the page number (zero to begin with) so we know which page to send back.

Then it’s just a matter of using LIMITed queries to return a subset of the highscores. The queries would be no different to those used to populate a web page.

Clicking a player’s name from within the current page view would issue the search by player packet.

Finally, the server response would be the information requested or a response indicative of throttling taking place (abuse prevention, because we are performing IO for every request after all).[/quote]The information required to fit on the screen is pretty high, and the client window is rather small. Do you have an idea already for what it would look like?

Also, that’s a lot more work than just designing a simple site, and I’m not sure people would even care enough about it. I mean, it could be amazing if we pulled it off, but I think there are other things that need to be done first.

[hr]

I just realized we could publish the top people for each skill using Google Docs and have it auto update. All we’d have to do is make the document viewable by the public. We could even have a separate spreadsheet with the full highscores, but it might take a bit to load (though I don’t think it’d be too bad).

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I wasn’t talking about loading a site within the client so much as introducing some new packets that would allow for pagination and searching my username.

So you’d basically have these client to server packets:

  1. Search by player name.
  2. Search by skill, page number. (Opcode, skill id, page number).
  3. Search by rank (Opcode, skill id, rank).

The search by player name would simply return the stats for that player, or a ‘not found’ code.
The search by skill would involve sending a valid skill id to order by that skill, or a negative skill id to indicate ordering by overall level. It would also send the page number (zero to begin with) so we know which page to send back.

Then it’s just a matter of using LIMITed queries to return a subset of the highscores. The queries would be no different to those used to populate a web page.

Clicking a player’s name from within the current page view would issue the search by player packet.

Finally, the server response would be the information requested or a response indicative of throttling taking place (abuse prevention, because we are performing IO for every request after all).

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:4, topic:528260”]You don’t send all of the data at once to the client - just the contents of the current page.[/quote]I don’t see how you’re going to search with a static site without offloading it to the client.

Like, we could generate all the highscores tables and link them automatically if you don’t have a search function. PasteHTML has an API for automating it, so it would be really easy.

I guess you could have a separate page for searching that just gives people all the data.

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

You don’t send all of the data at once to the client - just the contents of the current page.

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

Account creation is going to be handled through the client and will be linked to your Reddit account (for account recovery and such)

Creating a high scores via client wouldn’t be difficult, it’s just a ton of data to send to the client. Especially if it has to load all the player files separately and parse it…

CFFs logic.

For highscores, I suppose you could make a sticky in the subreddit with a link to a site that just hosts some HTML, like pastehtml.com and it just retrieves the JSON data from something like PasteBin.

Read full topic

item.title: MoparClassic High Scores
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

That would actually make this whole reddit/forum idea really cool, and original

Read full topic
